title: Getting started with 'ggmapinset'
text: example uses mosquito surveillance dataset ggmapinset::mozzies_nsw2301. includes points across New South Wales. Firstly, can recreate basic maps report accompanying dataset. Since dataset latitude longitude coordinates, can easily converted spatial data frame sf::st_as_sf().  warning sf::st_point_on_surface can disregarded. errors due coordinate system unlikely make much visual difference text placed case. plot looks little congested. can improve things bit using repulsive version label geom ggrepel:  main thing note geom_text_repel() hooked ggplot2’s geospatial integration, needs told use stat_sf_coordinates() compute coordinates, needs explicit mapping geometry aesthetic. improved map except Sydney region labels missing since overlap. max.overlaps parameter geom_text_repel() can help, doesn’t address overcrowding issue. inset can help. First define inset want. can collect points dataset labelled type == "sydney" use standard geospatial functions get diameter centre circle cover points. specify want circle enlarged factor 4, shifted south east: Finally, can repeat previous plot _inset version relevant layers. inset configuration passed coord. change make sure labels Sydney sites appear inset instead base map, need remap x y aesthetics versions computed underlying stat.  tweaks label placement can achieved playing around parameters geom_text_repel(), passing vectors positions nudge_x nudge_y parameters.
code: head(mozzies_nsw2301) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   location week_ending species             count type     lat  long #>   <chr>    <date>      <fct>               <ord> <fct>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Albury   2023-01-07  Culex annulirostris low   inland -36.1  147. #> 2 Albury   2023-01-07  Aedes vigilax       NA    inland -36.1  147. #> 3 Albury   2023-01-07  total               low   inland -36.1  147. #> 4 Albury   2023-01-14  Culex annulirostris high  inland -36.1  147. #> 5 Albury   2023-01-14  Aedes vigilax       NA    inland -36.1  147. #> 6 Albury   2023-01-14  total               high  inland -36.1  147. library(dplyr) library(sf)  # just take the total count from a single week of the data mozzies <- mozzies_nsw2301 |>   filter(species == "total", week_ending == as.Date("2023-01-07")) |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("long", "lat"), crs = st_crs("WGS84"))  labels <- c("Low (<50)", "Medium (50-100)", "High (101-1,000)",             "Very High (1,001-10,000)", "Extreme (>10,000)")  scale1 <- scale_colour_manual(   name = NULL,   values = c("green", "gold", "darkorange", "red", "black"),   labels = labels,   na.value = "grey",   drop = FALSE ) scale2 <- scale_size_ordinal(   name = NULL,   labels = labels,   range = c(3, 5),   na.value = 2,   drop = FALSE )  ggplot(mozzies) +   geom_sf(data = nswgeo::nsw, fill = NA) +   geom_sf(aes(size = count, colour = count)) +   geom_sf_text(aes(label = location), hjust = 0, nudge_x = 0.25, size = 3) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(NA, 158)) +   scale1 + scale2 +   theme_void() #> Warning in st_point_on_surface.sfc(sf::st_zm(x)): st_point_on_surface may not #> give correct results for longitude/latitude data library(ggrepel)  ggplot(mozzies) +   geom_sf(data = nswgeo::nsw, fill = NA) +   geom_sf(aes(size = count, colour = count)) +   geom_text_repel(     aes(label = location, geometry = geometry),     hjust = 0,     nudge_x = 0.25,     size = 3,     max.overlaps = 15,     point.padding = 0,     min.segment.length = 1,     stat = "sf_coordinates"   ) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(NA, 158)) +   scale1 + scale2 +   theme_void() #> Warning in st_point_on_surface.sfc(sf::st_zm(x)): st_point_on_surface may not #> give correct results for longitude/latitude data #> Warning: ggrepel: 7 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider #> increasing max.overlaps sydney <- filter(mozzies, type == "sydney") sydney_size <- st_distance(sydney, sydney) |> max() |> as.numeric() / 1000 sydney_centre <- st_union(sydney) |> st_centroid()  sydney_inset <- configure_inset(   shape_circle(centre = sydney_centre, radius = sydney_size),   translation = c(400, -200),   scale = 4,   units = "km" ) ggplot(mozzies) +   geom_sf_inset(data = nswgeo::nsw, fill = NA) +   geom_sf_inset(aes(size = count, colour = count), map_base = "clip") +   geom_text_repel(     aes(       x = after_stat(x_inset),       y = after_stat(y_inset),       label = location,       geometry = geometry     ),     hjust = 0,     nudge_x = 0.25,     size = 3,     force_pull = 2,     max.overlaps = Inf,     point.padding = 0,     min.segment.length = 1,     stat = "sf_coordinates_inset"   ) +   geom_inset_frame() +   coord_sf_inset(xlim = c(NA, 158), inset = sydney_inset) +   scale1 + scale2 +   theme_void()

title: Getting started with 'ggmapinset'
text: default, geom_sf_inset() creates two copies map layer: one base map inset map. inset transformed clipped, uses underlying aesthetics mapping parameters. want different aesthetics two layers, ’ll need turn copying map_base = "none". parameter set inset parameter provided, inset layer drawn. draw base layer, can use map_inset = "none", inset = NULL, simply use normal geom_sf().
code: ggplot(nc) +   # this is equivalent to the following line:   # geom_sf_inset(fill = "white", map_inset = "none") +   geom_sf(fill = "white") +   geom_sf_inset(aes(fill = AREA), map_base = "none") +   geom_inset_frame() +   coord_sf_inset(configure_inset(     shape_circle(       centre = sf::st_centroid(sf::st_geometry(nc)[nc$NAME == "Bladen"]),       radius = 50     ),     scale = 1.5, translation = c(-180, -50),  units = "mi"   ))

title: Getting started with 'ggmapinset'
text: default, inset frame transparent, although often makes sense add solid background inset distinguishable overlapping part base map. aesthetics two parts frame burst lines connecting can controlled separately. Note background filled, need specify base inset maps separate layers frame can slip .
code: ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = AREA)) +   geom_inset_frame(target.aes = list(fill = "white")) +   geom_sf_inset(aes(fill = AREA), map_base = "none") +   coord_sf_inset(configure_inset(     shape_circle(       centre = st_centroid(st_geometry(nc)[nc$NAME == "Yancey"]),       radius = 50     ),     scale = 2, translation = c(100, -120), units = "mi"   ))

title: Getting started with 'ggmapinset'
text: multiple insets, appropriate inset configuration just needs passed layer separately. ’s probably clearer avoid providing inset coordinate system case. Since inset-aware layers duplicate base inset maps, probably want disable behaviour map_base = "none" avoid multiple identical copies base map.
code: inset1 <- configure_inset(   shape_rectangle(     centre = sf::st_centroid(nc[nc$NAME == "Bladen", ]),     hwidth = 50   ),   scale = 1.5, translation = c(150, -50), units = "mi" ) #> Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries inset2 <- configure_inset(   shape_circle(     centre = sf::st_centroid(nc[nc$NAME == "Orange", ]),     radius = 30   ),   scale = 3, translation = c(30, 120), units = "mi" ) #> Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries inset3 <- configure_inset(   shape_sf(nc[nc$NAME == "Gates", ]),   scale = 6, translation = c(90, 70), units = "mi" )  ggplot(nc) +   # base map   geom_sf_inset() +   # inset 1   geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none", inset = inset1) +   geom_inset_frame(inset = inset1, colour = "red") +   # inset 2   geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none", inset = inset2) +   geom_inset_frame(inset = inset2, colour = "blue") +   # inset 3   geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none", inset = inset3, colour = NA) +   geom_inset_frame(inset = inset3, colour = "magenta")

code: @Manual{,   title = {ggmapinset: Add Inset Panels to Maps},   author = {Carl Suster},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.4.0.9000,   https://cidm-ph.github.io/ggmapinset/},   url = {https://github.com/cidm-ph/ggmapinset}, }

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: Add zoomed inset panels ggplot maps.

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: can install ggmapinset like :
code: # CRAN release install.packages('ggmapinset')  # development version install.packages('ggmapinset', repos = c('https://cidm-ph.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org'))

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: ggmapinset provides drop-replacements sf-related layers ggplot2: replacements work normal versions copy, zoom, clip layers make inset work. stats can used add inset support geoms third-party packages. extension developers, tools provided make sf-based layers inset-aware (see ggautomap examples).

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: example adds inset first example ggplot2::geom_sf(). inset area defined circle centred named county, radius 50 miles. inset enlarged factor 2 shifted empty part map.  information, see online documentation vignette("ggmapinset").
code: library(ggmapinset) library(ggplot2)  # load the North Carolina map example shipped with sf nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)  inset_cfg <- configure_inset(   shape_circle(     centre =  sf::st_centroid(nc[nc$NAME == "Yancey",]),     radius = 50   ),   scale = 2,   units = "mi",   translation = c(70, -180) ) #> Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries  # pick some counties to label labelled_counties <- sample(nc$NAME, 10) data_subset <- function(df) df[df$NAME %in% labelled_counties,] # base ggplot ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = AREA)) +      geom_sf_label(     aes(label = NAME),     data = data_subset   ) +   coord_sf() # with inset added ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf_inset(aes(fill = AREA)) +   geom_inset_frame() +   geom_sf_label_inset(     aes(label = NAME),     data = data_subset   ) +   coord_sf_inset(inset_cfg)

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: package implements insets duplicating transforming spatial data within single coordinate system. means don’t get separate grid lines inset panel , significantly, inset can distorted projection base map move far. tends problem practice choose coordinate system isn’t distorted area base map.

title: Add Inset Panels to Maps
text: packages implement different approaches: facet_zoom() ggforce geom_magnify() ggmagnify mf_inset_on() mapsf also several articles describing manual ways achieve different insets: https://www.datawim.com/post/inset-map--r/ https://dieghernan.github.io/202203_insetmaps/ https://upgo.lab.mcgill.ca/2019/12/13/making-beautiful-maps/

what: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
title: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
text: plotting, use geom_sf_inset() instead. helper intended used implementing custom geometries based geom_sf_inset() can provide parameters control inset.

title: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
code: build_sf_inset_layers(   data,   mapping,   stat,   position,   show.legend,   inherit.aes,   params,   inset,   map_base = "normal",   map_inset = "auto" )

title: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
text: data, mapping, stat, position, show.legend, inherit.aes, params See ggplot2::layer(). inset Inset configuration; see configure_inset(). NA (default), inherited coord (see coord_sf_inset()). map_base Controls layer base map. Possible values "normal" create layer though inset specified, "clip" create layer inset viewport cut , "none" prevent insertion layer base map. map_inset Controls layer inset map. Possible values "auto" choose behaviour based whether inset specified, "normal" create layer viewport cut transformed, "none" prevent insertion layer viewport map.

title: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
text: ggplot layer, pair layers.

title: Build layers to implement an inset-compatible geometry — build_sf_inset_layers
code: my_custom_geom <- function(   mapping = ggplot2::aes(),   data = NULL,   stat = "my_custom_stat",   position = "identity",   ...,   inset = NA,   map_base = "normal",   map_inset = "auto",   na.rm = TRUE,   inherit.aes = TRUE ) {   params <- rlang::list2(na.rm = na.rm, ...)   build_sf_inset_layers(     data = data, mapping = mapping,     stat = stat, position = position,     show.legend = show.legend,     inherit.aes = inherit.aes,     params = params,     inset = inset,     map_base = map_base,     map_inset = map_inset   ) }

what: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
text: configuration returned function often passed coordinate system via coord_sf_inset() propagated relevant layers.

title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
code: configure_inset(   shape,   scale = NULL,   translation = NULL,   units = "km",   crs_working = NULL,   centre = deprecated(),   radius = deprecated() )

title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
text: shape Inset shape: see shape_circle(), shape_rectangle(), shape_sf(). scale Zoom scale: values larger one make inset bigger. translation Translation (shift) inset relative centre. can sf::st_point() simply vector length 2 containing x y offsets respectively. Units specified crs_working. units Base length unit (e.g. "km" "mi"). Ignored crs_working provided. See Details supported values. crs_working coordinate reference system use internally applying transformations. See Details. centre, radius Use shape = shape_circle(centre, radius) instead.

title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
text: inset configuration object class inset_config.

title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
text: default crs_working uses equidistant cylindrical coordinate reference system latitude true scale set match latitude centre. ensures circular insets appear circular cases since projection distorted near centre. geometries converted CRS inset transformation constructing inset frame, converted back CRS centre end. default units kilometres can changed units instead specifying whole projection. possible values units understood proj: "mm": millimetre "cm": centimetre "m": metre "ft": foot "us-ft": US survey foot "fath": fathom "kmi": nautical mile "us-ch": US survey chain "us-mi": US survey mile "km": kilometre "ind-ft": Indian foot (1937) "ind-yd": Indian yard (1937) "mi": Statute mile "yd": yard "ch": chain "link": link "dm": decimeter "": inch "ind-ch": Indian chain "us-": US survey inch "us-yd": US survey yard

title: Configure transformations underpinning a map inset — configure_inset
code: library(sf)  # circular inset with a 2x enlargement cfg <- configure_inset(   shape_circle(centre = c(-82, 35), radius = 50),   scale = 2,   translation = c(70, -180),   units = "mi" ) #> Warning: `centre` has no coordinate reference system; assuming WGS 84 #> ℹ Provide `centre` as a `sf::st_sfc()` with an explicit `crs` to suppress.

what: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
title: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
text: allows default inset configuration provided avoid repeat layer. layer inset-aware can use default configuration none specifically provided layer. coord also expands axis limits include inset area.

title: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
code: coord_sf_inset(inset, ...)

title: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
text: inset Inset configuration; see configure_inset(). ... Arguments passed ggplot2::coord_sf()

title: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
text: ggplot coordinate object added plot.

title: Specify an inset configuration for the whole plot — coord_sf_inset
code: library(ggplot2)  nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)  ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf_inset(aes(fill = AREA)) +   geom_inset_frame() +   coord_sf_inset(inset = configure_inset(     centre = sf::st_sfc(sf::st_point(c(-80, 35.5)), crs = 4326),     scale = 1.5, translation = c(-50, -140), radius = 50, units = "mi")) #> Warning: The `radius` argument of `configure_inset()` is deprecated as of ggmapinset #> 0.4.0. #> ℹ Use `shape = shape_circle(centre, radius)` instead.

what: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
text: frame computed inset configuration, data passed layer ignored. frame sf object consisting three features: source area, target area (scaled translated version source area), connecting/burst lines.

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
code: geom_inset_frame(   mapping = ggplot2::aes(),   data = NULL,   stat = "sf_inset",   position = "identity",   ...,   inset = NA,   na.rm = FALSE,   source.aes = list(),   target.aes = list(),   lines.aes = list(),   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = FALSE )

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
text: mapping, data, stat, position, na.rm, show.legend, inherit.aes, ... See ggplot2::geom_sf(). inset Inset configuration; see configure_inset(). NA (default), inherited coord (see coord_sf_inset()). source.aes, target.aes, lines.aes Override aesthetics inset source, target, lines respectively. value list named aesthetics, values scalars length one.

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
text: ggplot layer holding inset frame.

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
text: Burst lines circular insets bitangenets (tangent source target circles) absent circles nested. Burst lines rectangular insets shortest line corner source rectangle corner target rectangle, excluding lines intersect either rectangle . burst lines absent due geometrical constraints, still corresponding (empty) feature frame layer's data.

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
text: frame drawn without another sf layer contains data due limitation ggplot layout evaluation. Attempting plot frame result error: "Scale limits mapped onto spatial coordinates coord_sf()".

title: Add a frame and burst lines for an inset — geom_inset_frame
code: library(ggplot2)  nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)  ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf_inset() +   geom_inset_frame(     source.aes = list(fill = "red", alpha = 0.2, linewidth = 0),     target.aes = list(colour = "blue"),     lines.aes = list(linetype = 2, linewidth = 2)   ) +   coord_sf_inset(inset = configure_inset(     shape_circle(centre = c(-82, 35), radius = 50),     scale = 5, translation = c(0, -260), units = "mi"   )) #> Warning: `centre` has no coordinate reference system; assuming WGS 84 #> ℹ Provide `centre` as a `sf::st_sfc()` with an explicit `crs` to suppress.

what: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
text: geoms wrappers around ggplot2::geom_sf() relatives assist creating map insets. many cases needed use coord_sf_inset() configure_inset() configure location transformation inset, replace sf-related geoms _inset counterparts. Use geom_inset_frame() add frame around inset connects main map.

title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
code: geom_sf_inset(   mapping = ggplot2::aes(),   data = NULL,   stat = "sf_inset",   position = "identity",   ...,   inset = NA,   map_base = "normal",   map_inset = "auto",   na.rm = TRUE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE )  stat_sf_inset(   mapping = ggplot2::aes(),   data = NULL,   geom = "sf_inset",   position = "identity",   ...,   inset = NA,   na.rm = TRUE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE )

title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
text: mapping, data, stat, geom, position, na.rm, show.legend, inherit.aes, ... See ggplot2::geom_sf(). inset Inset configuration; see configure_inset(). NA (default), inherited coord (see coord_sf_inset()). map_base Controls layer base map. Possible values "normal" create layer though inset specified, "clip" create layer inset viewport cut , "none" prevent insertion layer base map. map_inset Controls layer inset map. Possible values "auto" choose behaviour based whether inset specified, "normal" create layer viewport cut transformed, "none" prevent insertion layer viewport map.

title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
text: ggplot layer similar ggplot2::geom_sf() transformed according inset configuration.

title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
text: Internally works creating two layers: one base map, one inset. can separately controlled map_base map_inset parameters. inset specified, geom instead behave like ggplot2::geom_sf(). inset configured, default creates base inset layers using aesthetic mapping params:   can alternatively specify two layers separately:   stat_sf_inset() works ggplot2::stat_sf() except also expands axis limits account inset area.
code: geom_sf_inset(...) # draw the base map only (both versions are equivalent): geom_sf(...) geom_sf_inset(..., map_inset = "none")  # separately, draw the inset map only: geom_sf_inset(..., map_base = "none")

title: Visualise sf objects with insets — geom_sf_inset
code: library(ggplot2)  nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)  ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf_inset(aes(fill = AREA)) +   geom_inset_frame() +   coord_sf_inset(configure_inset(     shape_circle(       centre = sf::st_sfc(sf::st_point(c(-80, 35.5)), crs = sf::st_crs(nc)),       radius = 50     ),     scale = 1.5, translation = c(-50, -140), units = "mi"   ))

what: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
title: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
text: helper implementing inset-aware ggplot layers. inset missing (NA) default inset configuration retrieved coord.

title: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
code: get_inset_config(inset, coord)

title: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
text: inset Inset passed param layer coord Coord object plot

title: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
text: Inset configuration NULL

title: Get the inset configuration from the params or coord — get_inset_config
code: # defining a new geom deriving from geom_sf() GeomCustom <- ggplot2::ggproto("GeomCustom", ggplot2::GeomSf,   draw_panel = function(self, data, panel_params, coord, inset = NA) {     inset <- get_inset_config(inset, coord)      # do something with the inset ...      # note that this example doesn't pass on the remaining geom_sf params but     # in real usage you would probably want to do that     ggplot2::ggproto_parent(ggplot2::GeomSf, self)$draw_panel(data, panel_params, coord)   }, )

what: Add Inset Panels to Maps — ggmapinset-package

what: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
title: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
text: dataset derived NSW Arbovirus Surveillance Mosquito Monitoring program. program monitors mosquito-borne diseases state New South Wales, Australia. number mosquito traps managed program spring autumn months mosquitoes active.

title: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
code: mozzies_nsw2301

title: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
text: Data frame following fields: location Location mosquito trap week_ending Date end week observation species Mosquito species counted, "total" total count count Binned mosquito abundance type Category site lat Latitude trap WGS 84 coordinates long Longitude trap WGS 84 coordinates

title: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
text: Surveillance Risk Unit, Environmental Health Branch, Health Protection NSW, NSW Health. "NSW Arbovirus Surveillance Mosquito Monitoring 2022-2023; Weekly Update: Week ending 25 February 2023 (Report Number 19)" https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/environment/pests/vector/Publications/nswasp-weekly-report-2023-02-25.pdf, accessed 15 January 2024. original dataset published Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 licence © State New South Wales NSW Ministry Health 2023.

title: Mosquito counts from NSW Arbovirus Surveillance program — mozzies_nsw2301
text: week traps collected mosquito species identified counted. analysed alongside climate conditions, arbovirus detections traps inform public health management human disease risk arboviruses NSW. dataset includes mosquito abundance tables January 2023. Additional context analysis can found original report published NSW Health. trap locations classified inland coastal (since species found depend environmental conditions). separate group sites labelled Sydney region (.e. highest human population density). counts binned following definition: NA observation low < 50 medium 50 - 100 high 101 - 1,000 high 1,001 - 10,000 extreme > 10,000

title: Circular insets — shape_circle
text: Circular insets

title: Circular insets — shape_circle
code: shape_circle(centre, radius)

title: Circular insets — shape_circle
text: centre Coordinates inset centre. Ideally sfc object (see sf::st_sfc()) including coordinate reference system. sf::st_point() vector longitude latitude also accepted. CRS determined, WGS 84 assumed. radius Radius inset circle units inset's crs_working.

title: Circular insets — shape_circle
text: shape definition suitable use configure_inset().

title: Circular insets — shape_circle
code: library(ggplot2) nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE) make_demo <- function(...) {   ggplot(nc) +     geom_sf(fill = "grey95", colour = "grey85") +     # For a filled frame, we want to interleave it between the base layer     # (above this line) and the target layer (below the following line).     geom_inset_frame(target.aes = list(fill = "white")) +     geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none") +     coord_sf_inset(inset = configure_inset(...)) +     theme_void() } circle <- shape_circle(sf::st_centroid(nc[21,]), radius = 50) #> Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries  make_demo(circle, scale = 3, translation = c(-200, -200))  make_demo(circle, scale = 3, translation = c(-100, -100))  make_demo(circle, scale = 3, translation = c(0, 0))  make_demo(circle, scale = 0.5, translation = c(0, 0))

title: Rectangular insets — shape_rectangle
text: Rectangular insets

title: Rectangular insets — shape_rectangle
code: shape_rectangle(centre, hwidth, hheight = NULL)

title: Rectangular insets — shape_rectangle
text: centre Coordinates inset centre. Ideally sfc object (see sf::st_sfc()) including coordinate reference system. sf::st_point() vector longitude latitude also accepted. CRS determined, WGS 84 assumed. hwidth Half width inset units inset's crs_working. hheight Half height inset units inset's crs_working. Defaults value hwidth.

title: Rectangular insets — shape_rectangle
text: shape definition suitable use configure_inset().

title: Rectangular insets — shape_rectangle
code: library(ggplot2) nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE) make_demo <- function(...) {   ggplot(nc) +     geom_sf(fill = "grey95", colour = "grey85") +     # For a filled frame, we want to interleave it between the base layer     # (above this line) and the target layer (below the following line).     geom_inset_frame(target.aes = list(fill = "white")) +     geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none") +     coord_sf_inset(inset = configure_inset(...)) +     theme_void() } rectangle <- shape_rectangle(sf::st_centroid(nc[21,]), hwidth = 50, hheight = 40) #> Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries  make_demo(rectangle, scale = 3, translation = c(-300, 0))  make_demo(rectangle, scale = 3, translation = c(-250, -200))  make_demo(rectangle, scale = 3, translation = c(-150, -100))  make_demo(rectangle, scale = 3, translation = c(0, 0))  make_demo(rectangle, scale = 0.5, translation = c(0, 0))

title: Arbitrary geometry as insets — shape_sf

title: Arbitrary geometry as insets — shape_sf
text: shape definition suitable use configure_inset().

title: Arbitrary geometry as insets — shape_sf
code: library(ggplot2) nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE) make_demo <- function(...) {   ggplot(nc) +     geom_sf(fill = "grey95", colour = "grey85") +     # For a filled frame, we want to interleave it between the base layer     # (above this line) and the target layer (below the following line).     geom_inset_frame(target.aes = list(fill = "white")) +     geom_sf_inset(map_base = "none", colour = NA) +     coord_sf_inset(inset = configure_inset(...)) +     theme_void() } shape <- shape_sf(nc[21,])  make_demo(shape, scale = 6, translation = c(-200, -200))  make_demo(shape, scale = 6, translation = c(-100, -100))  make_demo(shape, scale = 6, translation = c(100, 100))  make_demo(shape, scale = 0.5, translation = c(0, 0))

title: Extract coordinates from 'sf' objects (inset-aware) — geom_sf_text_inset
text: Reduce spatial data coordinates way stat_sf_coordinates(). result can used geom_sf() geom_sf_inset() geom needs x y aesthetics. particularly useful text, wrappers provided geom_text() geom_label().

title: Extract coordinates from 'sf' objects (inset-aware) — geom_sf_text_inset
code: geom_sf_text_inset(   mapping = aes(),   data = NULL,   stat = "sf_coordinates_inset",   position = "identity",   ...,   where = "inset",   parse = FALSE,   check_overlap = FALSE,   na.rm = FALSE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE,   fun.geometry = NULL )  geom_sf_label_inset(   mapping = aes(),   data = NULL,   stat = "sf_coordinates_inset",   position = "identity",   ...,   where = "inset",   parse = FALSE,   na.rm = FALSE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE,   fun.geometry = NULL )  stat_sf_coordinates_inset(   mapping = ggplot2::aes(),   data = NULL,   geom = "point",   position = "identity",   ...,   inset = NA,   fun.geometry = NULL,   where = "inset",   na.rm = TRUE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE )

title: Extract coordinates from 'sf' objects (inset-aware) — geom_sf_text_inset
text: mapping, data, geom, position, na.rm, show.legend, inherit.aes, fun.geometry, ... See ggplot2::stat_sf_coordinates(). stat, parse, check_overlap See ggplot2::geom_sf_text(). Specifies text position interacts inset. "inset" means points inset area drawn inset map, "base" puts base map. setting merely shorthand setting position aesthetics after_stat(x_inset) after_stat(x) respectively, effect specified mapping. inset Inset configuration; see configure_inset(). NA (default), inherited coord (see coord_sf_inset()).

title: Extract coordinates from 'sf' objects (inset-aware) — geom_sf_text_inset
text: x X dimension simple feature y Y dimension simple feature x_inset X dimension simple feature inset transformation y_inset Y dimension simple feature inset transformation inside_inset logical indicating points inside inset viewport inset_scale 1 points outside inset, otherwise configured inset scale parameter

title: Extract coordinates from 'sf' objects (inset-aware) — geom_sf_text_inset
code: library(ggplot2)  nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)  ggplot(nc) +   geom_sf_inset() +   geom_inset_frame() +   geom_sf_text(     aes(x = after_stat(x_inset), y = after_stat(y_inset), label = NAME),     stat = "sf_coordinates_inset") +   coord_sf_inset(configure_inset(     shape_circle(       centre = sf::st_sfc(sf::st_point(c(-80, 35.5)), crs = 4326),       radius = 50     ),     scale = 1.5, translation = c(-50, -140), units = "mi"   ))

title: Transform coordinates according to inset configuration — transform_to_inset
ggmapinset 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-12-18 Added support rectangular insets via shape_rectangle(). Added support arbitrary insets via shape_sf().

title: ggmapinset 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-04-28 Replaced confusing inset_clip inset_copy parameters geom_sf_inset() new map_base map_inset parameters. Inset frame aesthetics can now specified consistently. default inset configuration can passed coord_sf_inset() avoid repeating every layer. Insets now based stat_sf_inset() correctly adjusts coordinate limits computes inset-related variables downstream use. new stat_sf_coordinates_inset(), geom_sf_text_inset(), geom_sf_label_inset() labels complete coverage sf-related layers. Added transform_to_inset() helper applying inset transformation arbitrary geometries (extension developers).

title: ggmapinset 0.2.3
text: CRAN release: 2023-02-21 Initial CRAN release.
